title: Sprint Review & Demos
description: Master Sprint Review—collaboration and feedback (not formal approval), Definition of Done, cycle time measurement, and MVP concepts.
objectives: Distinguish Sprint Review (product-oriented, collaboration) from Sprint Retrospective (process-oriented)
Recognize Sprint Review is for COLLABORATION and feedback, NOT formal approval/signoff
Apply Definition of Done (DoD) as criteria for increment readiness
Calculate cycle time (start-to-finish time for product increment)
Recognize Minimum Viable Product (MVP) as prototype with just enough features for feedback

screens.headline: Morgan brings an acceptance document to Sprint Review. 'I need your formal signoff.' Alex says: 'That's not how Agile works.' Who's right?

items.label: Predictive
items.detail: Morgan signing acceptance document, formal gate, STOP sign

items.label: Agile
items.detail: Team presenting, stakeholders giving feedback, collaborative circle

dialogue.text: Sprint Review is NOT a formal approval gate. It's a COLLABORATION session—we demo the work, gather feedback, and adapt. No signoff required. That's the Agile difference.

screens.learningHook: Learn Sprint Review's TRUE purpose, how it differs from Retrospective, Definition of Done, and cycle time measurement.

screens.title: Sprint Review Scenarios
screens.instructions: Make decisions about Sprint Review purpose, distinguishing from Retrospective, Definition of Done, and cycle time.

scenarios.title: Morgan's Acceptance Document
description: Morgan presents 'Acceptance Document': 'I need formal sign-off on these 3 dishes before proceeding.'
Alex objects: 'Sprint Review isn't about formal approval.'

questions.question: What is the PRIMARY purpose of Sprint Review in Agile?

options.text: Formal approval and sign-off by Product Owner
Collaboration: demonstrate work, gather feedback, adapt priorities
Team reflects on process improvements
Plan the next sprint

feedback.correct: Sprint Review is COLLABORATION—demo increment, stakeholders provide feedback, Product Owner may re-prioritize backlog. NO formal sign-off required.
feedback.incorrect: Sprint Review = collaboration (product feedback). Sprint Retrospective = process reflection. Sprint Planning = next sprint work.

scenarios.title: Process Improvement During Review
description: During Sprint Review, Maya asks: 'Can we discuss changing standup time from 9am to 10am?'
Devon: 'Also, I'd like to talk about story point estimation.'

questions.question: How should Taylor respond to process improvement suggestions during Sprint Review?

options.text: Discuss now—Sprint Review covers all team topics
'Great process topics—save for Sprint Retrospective. Review focuses on product increment.'
Cancel Retrospective since we're discussing process now
Address in both Review AND Retrospective

feedback.correct: Sprint Review = product-oriented (WHAT we built). Sprint Retrospective = process-oriented (HOW we worked). Keep them separate for focus.
feedback.incorrect: Review = product feedback with stakeholders. Retrospective = process improvement (team only). Different purposes.

scenarios.title: Mediterranean Ramen 90% Complete
description: Maya: 'Mediterranean ramen is 90% complete—recipe done, plating done, taste test passed.'
'But nutrition analysis is missing (DoD requirement). Should we demo it?'

questions.question: Should team demonstrate Mediterranean ramen if it hasn't met ALL DoD criteria?

options.text: Yes—demo as 90% complete, explain what's missing
No—only demo increments that meet Definition of Done (potentially shippable)
Yes—but don't count it as 'Done' for velocity
Ask Morgan to waive nutrition analysis requirement

feedback.correct: Sprint Review demonstrates POTENTIALLY SHIPPABLE increments—meeting DoD. If nutrition analysis is missing, increment isn't Done. Wait until it meets all DoD criteria.
feedback.incorrect: DoD is non-negotiable. Partially done work isn't shippable. Complete it next sprint, then demo.

scenarios.title: Cycle Time Reporting
description: Carlos asks: 'Korean BBQ sushi looks great. How long from start to finish?'
Started Day 1 Sprint 2, completed Day 8 Sprint 3 (2-week sprints = 10 days each).

questions.question: What metric answers 'How long did it take from start to finish?'

options.text: Lead time (request to delivery)
Cycle time (start to finish)
Velocity (story points per sprint)
Takt time (time between outputs)

feedback.correct: Cycle time = start-to-finish time for one increment. Korean BBQ sushi: 10 days (Sprint 2) + 8 days (Sprint 3) = 18 days cycle time.
feedback.incorrect: Lead time = request to delivery. Velocity = throughput per sprint. Takt time = pace between outputs. Cycle time = start to finish.

purpose: GATHER feedback from PO and stakeholders
ADAPT product backlog based on feedback
whatItIsNot: NOT formal approval gate (no sign-off documents)
content.pmbokRef: Essential Scrum page 372; PMBOK 7th Ed page 180
Agile Practice Guide page 55; PMBOK 7th Ed page 180

content.definition: Checklist of required criteria for considering increment 'Done' and ready for delivery
content.whyMatters: Prevents 'almost done' syndrome, ensures consistent quality, supports velocity calculation

content.leadTime: Request to delivery (includes wait time before work starts)
content.velocity: Throughput—story points per sprint (HOW MUCH, not HOW LONG)

correct.text: I see now—Sprint Review is collaborative, not a formal gate. Feedback drives improvement, not sign-offs. This is way more effective.
We only demo potentially shippable work—increments meeting DoD. If nutrition analysis is missing, we wait. Quality isn't optional.

screens.title: MVP Demo Planning
screens.context: Ava wants to demo meal kit concept to investors. Team has basic version (ordering, core recipes) but premium features aren't ready. She asks: 'Should we wait for full product or demo what we have?'

options.text: Wait until full product is ready—investors want polished version
Demo MVP (minimum viable product)—get early feedback on core concept

questions.question: What is the purpose of MVP demo?

options.text: Prove product is complete and ready for market
Get early feedback to guide future development
Lock in final requirements with investors

screens.title: Sprint Review Mastery
screens.summary: Sprint Review is collaboration (not formal approval), demonstrates potentially shippable increments (meeting DoD), and gathers feedback for backlog refinement.
takeaways: Sprint Review = collaboration, NOT formal approval (no sign-off)
Sprint Review = product-oriented; Sprint Retrospective = process-oriented
Only demo increments meeting Definition of Done
Cycle time = start-to-finish for one increment
MVP = minimum viable product for early feedback

artifacts.title: Sprint Review Guide
artifacts.description: Review vs Retrospective comparison, DoD checklist, cycle time calculation

characterClosing.text: I brought an acceptance document for sign-off. Alex showed me: Sprint Review is about COLLABORATION. Feedback from Carlos and Ava makes our dishes better. No signoff needed—continuous improvement.
